channel.title: NYT > World News

item.title: More Than a Million Afghans Flee as Economy Collapses
item.description: Thousands of Afghans are trying to sneak into Iran and Pakistan each day, as incomes have dried up and life-threatening hunger has become widespread.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: As Putin Blames West, Russia’s Military Buildup Continues
item.description: Satellite images captured the establishment of tents and shelters for troops near Ukraine’s borders. It may signal an increased “overall readiness level” of Russia’s military.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Marines during the 2018 NATO Trident Juncture exercise in Norway.

item.title: Conditions at a GM Plant in Mexico Spur a Labor Challenge
item.description: Mexican salaries are low, partly because of unions that collude with employers. Workers at a G.M. factory are challenging that system, testing the labor reforms in the reworked North American trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guillermo Ramírez sitting on his bed after work next to the oxygen tank used by his hospitalized daughter. “You’re earning so little,” he said. “It makes you feel useless.”

item.title: Erin O'Toole, Canada’s Conservative Leader, Is Ousted
item.description: The deposal of the Conservative leader Erin O’Toole could provide a political lift for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, buffeted by pandemic exhaustion.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
item.media:description: Erin O’Toole, the leader of Canada’s Conservative Party, at the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa.

item.title: One Day in the ‘Parallel Universe’ of a London I.C.U.
item.description: Britain’s government may have lifted coronavirus restrictions, but hospital workers say the return to a normal rhythm of work is still a long way off.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the New York Times
item.media:description: Health care staff have warned that a return to the normal rhythm of hospital care is still a long way off.

item.title: In Clash With U.S. Over Ukraine, Putin Has a Lifeline From China
item.description: President Biden could find his plans to punish Russia undermined by Xi Jinping, a longtime ally of Mr. Putin. But China moves cautiously during crises.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Edward Wong
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, left, with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, in Moscow in 2019. The two will meet Friday before the start of the Olympics in Beijing.

item.title: U.S. and NATO Don't Budge in Answering Russian Demands
item.description: Leaked replies to Moscow’s security demands reinforced the intractability of a crisis that threatens to lead to war.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front line position in Eastern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: With Low-Tech, Trench Warfare, Ukraine’s Army Isn’t NATO Caliber
item.description: The United States and its allies have trained and helped equip the Ukrainian army. But it has little resemblance to the kind of sophisticated, contemporary military that distinguishes NATO members.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on a front line position in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: At Least 60 Dead in Attack on Camp for Displaced People in Congo
item.description: The attack, which was carried out with guns and machetes, was among the worst recorded in eastern Congo, a lush region where dozens of militant groups have wreaked havoc for years.
item.dc:creator: Steve Wembi and Abdi Latif Dahir

item.title: Turkey Blames Greece After 12 Migrants Freeze to Death
item.description: A Turkish minister accused Greek border guards of taking the group’s clothes and shoes and then forcing them back across the border, a claim that Greece denied.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Safak Timur
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants near Turkey's Ipsala border crossing in 2020. Turkey is a major route for those trying to reach the E.U. from Asia, Africa and the Middle East.

item.title: Where a Thousand Digital Eyes Keep Watch Over the Elderly
item.description: As Japan rapidly ages, it is envisioning fundamental changes, even in infrastructure. Is electronic surveillance an answer to its epidemic of dementia?
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: One of about 1,200 digital surveillance units in Itami, Japan.

item.title: In Congo, Floating Pastors Follow Mobile Flocks Along Busy River
item.description: To find the faithful, preachers in some areas of the Democratic Republic of Congo hold church where the crowds are, on boats traveling the country’s water highway.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Caleb Kabanda and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:description: The Super Malou Express and other boats docked along the Congo River in Mbandaka in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Israeli Commanders Disciplined in Death of Palestinian-American Man
item.description: Three Israeli military commanders have been reprimanded and reassigned after an investigation into the death of a 78-year-old man after he was detained.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A poster with a picture of Omar Abdelmajed Assad in his West Bank village of Jiljilya, in January.

item.title: Report on London Police Highlights Culture of Misogyny and Racism
item.description: Britain’s police watchdog says the London force needs to address “disgraceful” behavior after an investigation found widespread bullying, discrimination and sexual harassment.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: London police officers at a vigil to remember Sarah Everard, who was raped and murdered by a Metropolitan Police Service officer in 2021.

item.title: Year of the Tiger Overshadows the Olympic Panda
item.description: In Beijing, the Lunar New Year has been a bigger preoccupation for many residents, while others have gone back to their hometowns for the holiday.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: In Beijing on Monday.

item.title: How Malaysia Got in on the Secondhand Clothing Boom
item.description: Sellers from the country have become a reliable source of sought-after labels, finding high value in discarded items.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Marcus
item.media:credit: Ian Teh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sora Bundle in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, is one of many secondhand stores in the country.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Military developments in Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Is Biden’s Strategy With Putin Working, or Goading Moscow to War?
item.description: The Biden administration’s goal is to cut the Russians off at each turn by exposing their plans. But Russian President Vladimir V. Putin says that approach could spark a conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has accused the United States of reviving the Cold War strategy of containment and trying to goad him into an attack.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. to Send Troops to Eastern Europe
item.description: The move may reassure NATO allies anxious over tensions surrounding Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a house near the front-line in Chermalyk, Ukraine.

item.title: As Boris Johnson Seeks a Reset, More Tory Lawmakers Defect
item.description: Britain’s prime minister tried to steer attention away from a damning report on Downing Street parties, but his support continued to erode.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain departing 10 Downing Street for Parliament on Wednesday in London.

item.title: U.S. Army Will Begin Dismissing Unvaccinated Soldiers
item.description: Other branches of the military, including the Air Force, have already begun discharging members who refused to comply with the mandate.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier prepared vaccine doses for administration at Fort Bragg, N.C., last year. Active-duty soldiers had until Dec. 15 to get vaccinated or request an exemption.

item.title: Why Nasal Covid Vaccines May Make Better Boosters
item.description: Nasal vaccines under development around the world may make better boosters by stopping the coronavirus in the airways.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Amarjeet Kumar Singh/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Waiting after a booster shot of the Covaxin vaccine, manufactured by Bharat Biotech, in New Delhi last month. The company now has approval to begin Phase 3 trials of its nasal vaccine.

item.title: Five Takeaways on Ukraine Crisis, After Putin Breaks Silence
item.description: The threat of conflict may not have passed, despite a flurry of diplomacy in Moscow and Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the front lines near Trokhizbenka in eastern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Trial Guide: The U.S.S. Cole Bombing Case at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: What to know about the death-penalty prosecution of a Saudi prisoner accused of plotting the attack on a Navy destroyer off Yemen in 2000 that killed 17 sailors.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Cole was attacked by suicide bombers during a routine refueling stop in the port of Aden, Yemen on Oct. 12, 2000.

item.title: Astronomers Find a New Trojan Asteroid Sharing Earth’s Orbit
item.description: The Trojan asteroid 2020 XL5, which follows the same path around the sun as our planet, was revealed only after a decade of searching.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Part-Time Work During a Labor Shortage
item.description: A tight job market is unlikely to reverse inequality.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brenda Garcia.

item.title: When Is Opening Ceremony for the Winter Olympics?
item.description: The Winter Games kick off Friday night at Beijing’s National Stadium.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Beijing Olympic Tower decorated with festive lights and lanterns in advance of the Opening Ceremony.

item.title: Shintaro Ishihara, Outspoken Nationalist Governor of Tokyo, Dies at 89
item.description: An author as well as a politician, he was known for feuding with China over disputed islands and calling for Japan to assert itself against the United States.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Japanese nationalist politician Shintaro Ishihara in 2011. He carried out a staunch right-wing campaign that he believed would reinvigorate Japan and free it from servility to the United States.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Putin blames the U.S. for the standoff over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons at a bar in Moscow on Tuesday as President Vladimir V. Putin spoke during a televised meeting with Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary.

item.title: Tonga Goes Into Lockdown Over Covid Cases
item.description: Among the infected are two workers who were helping to distribute aid shipments at the Tongan wharf after a volcanic eruption and tsunami tested positive.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mary Lyn Fonua/Matangi Tonga, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Australian Navy ship the H.M.A.S. Adelaide has been stranded by a power outage while docked at Vuna Wharf in Tonga's capital, Nukualofa, since last month.

item.title: U.S. Sends Official to Help NATO Brace for Russian Cyberattacks
item.description: Intelligence assessments suggest that a Russian invasion of Ukraine would most likely be preceded by cyberattacks on Ukraine’s electric grid, its communications systems and its government.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The trip by Anne Neuberger, the White House’s top cybersecurity official, is largely focused on how to coordinate a NATO response should Russia attack Ukraine’s power grid or communications systems.

item.title: Putin Signals Openness to Diplomacy While Blaming US for Crisis
item.description: The Russian president seemed to be trying to ratchet down tensions in the standoff over Ukraine, while claiming the United States was seeking to goad Moscow into an invasion.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons at a bar in Moscow on Tuesday as President Vladimir V. Putin spoke during a televised meeting with Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Blames the U.S.
item.description: The Russian president accused the U.S. of inciting war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin talks during a press conference with Hungarian Prime Minister after their meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow.

item.title: President of Guinea-Bissau Reasserts Control After Fears of Another Coup in Africa
item.description: Military leaders have taken power in five African countries in the last 18 months, but Guinea-Bissau — a small coastal nation no stranger to coups — appears to have just staved one off.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: People near the Guinea-Bissau government palace in the capital, Bissau, on Tuesday.

item.title: ABC Suspends Whoopi Goldberg Over Holocaust Comments
item.description: Ms. Goldberg’s comments, on Monday’s episode of “The View,” came amid growing ignorance about the Holocaust and rising antisemitism. She has apologized.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Neil Vigdor
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Anders Behring Breivik, Norwegian Terrorist, Is Denied Parole
item.description: Mr. Breivik, who killed 77 people in two attacks, has served 10 years of a 21-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:description: Anders Behring Breivik at his parole hearing in Skien prison, Norway, on Jan. 19. The hearing revived memories of the massacre and showcased the extremist views of Norway’s neo-Nazi fringe.

item.title: National Guard Is Not Exempt From Vaccine Mandate, Defense Secretary Says
item.description: Lloyd J. Austin’s rejection of the governors’ request to exempt their states’ troops from the national military coronavirus vaccine mandate sets the stage for a possible court fight.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joel Martinez/The Monitor, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In Texas, one of seven states whose governors sought to exempt National Guard troops from the military’s vaccine mandate, troops stood by in October during a news conference held in Mission by Gov. Greg Abbott.

item.title: Watch: The U.S. and Russia exchange bitter accusations at the U.N. Security Council.
item.media:description: Russia and the United States clashed at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Monday over a massive Russian military buildup on the Ukrainian border.

item.title: Hungary’s leader, visiting Moscow, calls Russian demands reasonable and says sanctions are pointless.
item.description: On a friendly visit to Moscow, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary diverged sharply from his NATO and European Union allies.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary last year in Slovenia.

item.title: Prices and Ire, Rising
item.description: Inflation is up, and Americans are mad. But it’s not a simple story.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas station in Los Angeles.

item.title: As the U.S. Pulls Back From the Mideast, China Leans In
item.description: China is expanding its ties to Middle Eastern states with vast infrastructure investments and cooperation on technology and security.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Amy Qin
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Prince Faisal bin Farhan al-Saud of Saudi Arabia, left, with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, in Wuxi, China, in January. China called the kingdom a “good partner” and “good brother.”

item.title: U.S. Orders Families of Embassy Staff to Leave Belarus
item.description: Washington cited “an increase in unusual and concerning Russian military activity near the border with Ukraine.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: In Minsk, the Belarusian capital, last month.

item.title: Groundhog Day: Munching Marmots Emerge From the Scientific Shadows
item.description: New research aims to shed light on the social habits of the popular, but often misunderstood, animal.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Keim and Greta Rybus
item.media:credit: Greta Rybus for The New York Times

item.title: Myanmar Is Mired in Conflict and Chaos a Year After a Coup
item.description: Daily protests, once loud and colorful, have been replaced by an eerie quiet. To mark the anniversary of the military takeover, protest leaders have called for a “silent strike.”
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A demonstrator making a three-finger protest symbol during a demonstration in Yangon, Myanmar, in February last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A diplomatic showdown at the U.N.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russia called the public meeting on the Ukraine crisis an example of “megaphone diplomacy,” while the U.S. criticized Russia, saying, “Imagine how uncomfortable you would be if you had 100,000 troops sitting at your border.”

item.title: U.S. and Allies Close to Reviving Nuclear Deal With Iran, Officials Say
item.description: A return to a 2015 accord is on the table, but the next decisions are up to the new government in Tehran, the Biden administration says.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Restoring the deal from 2015 would mean all limits on the production of nuclear material would still expire in 2030, at which point Iran would be free to resume the kind of fuel production it has underway now.

item.title: Angry US-Russia Exchange at UN Punctuates Deepening Ukraine Rift
item.description: With vitriolic accusations that echoed the Cold War era, the United States and Russia sparred in a bitter debate over the Ukraine crisis in a Security Council meeting watched by the world on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Russia and the United States clashed at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Monday over a massive Russian military buildup on the Ukrainian border.

item.title: Sue Gray's Report on Parties Deepens Crisis for Boris Johnson
item.description: A long-awaited assessment on whether Downing Street flouted lockdown rules declared that there were “failures of leadership and judgment’’ by Mr. Johnson’s government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain outside 10 Downing Street on Monday.

item.title: White House Ready With Sanctions on Putin's Inner Circle
item.description: The Biden administration said the penalties would exceed any levied recently against Russia. It is unclear whether the list of targets includes Vladimir V. Putin himself.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Designates Qatar as a Major Non-NATO Ally
item.description: The move clears the way for greater security cooperation and investment at a time when President Biden is seeking help boosting natural gas supplies in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, the emir of Qatar, and President Biden met at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Trudeau Condemns 'Freedom Convoy' Trucker Protest in Ottawa
item.description: The Canadian prime minister, who tested positive for Covid-19, railed against protesters for violence, racism and spreading misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday. Mr. Trudeau tested positive for the coronavirus after an exposure last week.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Diplomatic Clash Over Ukraine
item.description: Russians said the U.S. was fanning flames.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Russia and the United States clashed at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Monday.

item.title: For Some of Ukraine’s Neighbors, ‘Defend Europe’ Has Another Meaning
item.description: For the populist leaders of Poland and Hungary, Russia’s saber-rattling on the border with Ukraine takes a back seat to domestic politics and issues like immigration.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary on Saturday at a meeting of populist leaders in Madrid.

item.title: Putin and Macron Talk Again on Ukraine and De-Escalation
item.description: The two leaders discussed Ukraine and Russia’s demand for “security guarantees” that would include a legally binding halt on NATO expansion to the east.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking in 2020 with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia over a video call.
